ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

Gulf Bayport Chemicals, L.P. (formerly Lonza, Inc.) is committed to operating and maintaining all of our processes in a safe and responsible manner.  We use a combination of release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs to help ensure the safety of our employees and the public as well as to protect the environment.  A brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that we have designed and implemented include:

(1)  A description of our facility and use of substances regulated by EPA's RMP regulation
(2)  A summary of results from our assessment of the potential offsite consequences from accidental chemical  releases
(3)  An overview of our accidental release prevention programs
(4)  A five-year accident history for accidental releases of chemicals regulated by EPA's RMP rule
(5)  An overview of our emergency response program
(6)  An overview of planned changes to improve safety


1.0   STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

Gulf Bayport Chemicals, L.P. produces organic chemicals (Specialty Anhydrides) as intermediates for our customers to make epoxies, hardeners, resins, and food-grade applications (Starch modifiers).  The regulated substances listed in EPA's RMP rule in our facility are  Isoprene and 1,3-Pentadiene (Piperylene).  They are both flammable substances. The facility does not handle any listed toxic substances.


2.0   RELEASE SCENARIOS AND OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSES

The RMP rule requires that we provide information concerning the worst-case release scenario(s) and alternative release scenario(s) for our facility.  The following are brief summaries of these scenarios, including information about the key administrative control and mitigation measures to limit the distances for each reported scenario:

2.1  Worst-case Release  Scenarios - Regulated Toxic Substance

NA

2.2  Worst-case Release  Scenarios - Regulated Flammable Substance

Two worst-c

ase release scenarios from two regulated flammable substances are analyzed.  

One scenario is the rupture of the Isoprene storage tank with a maximum storage capacity of 124,000 pounds in the Tank Farm.  This is the largest storage tank of Isoprene, and the release will be contained in a concrete containment area.  This area is equipped with a deluge system and fire fighting equipment.  Assuming the released Isoprene has a vapor cloud explosion, the estimated affected endpoint is 0.1 miles according to the EPA's RMP Comp Modeling Program.  The potential public receptors include employees of the Quality Carriers plant.  Isoprene is used to produce specialty anhydrides.

The other scenario is the rupture of the 1,3-Pentadiene (Piperylene) storage tank with a maximum storage capacity of 117,000 pounds in the Tank Farm.  This is the largest storage tank of 1,3-Pentadiene, and the release will be contained in a concrete containment area.  This area is equipped with a deluge system and fire fighting equipment.  Assuming the released 1,3-Pentadiene has a vapor cloud explosion, the estimated affected endpoint is 0.1 miles according to the EPA's RMP Comp Modeling Program.  The potential public receptors include employees of the Quality Carriers plant. 1,3-Pentadiene is used to produce specialty anhydrides.

2.3  Alternative Release Scenarios - Regulated Toxic Substance

NA

2.4  Alternative Release Scenarios - Regulated Flammable Substances

Two alternative release scenarios from two regulated flammable substances are analyzed.  

One scenario is the puncture of the Isoprene storage tank with a maximum storage capacity of 124,000 pounds in the Tank Farm.  This is the largest storage tank of Isoprene, and the release, estimated at a rate of 14,500 pounds per hour, will be contained in a concrete containment area.  This area is equipped with a deluge system and fire fighting equipment.  Assuming the released Isoprene results in a vapor cloud fire, the estimated affected endpo

int is less than 0.1 miles according to the EPA's RMP Comp Modeling Program.  The potential public receptors include employees of the Quality Carriers plant.  Isoprene is used to produce specialty anhydrides. 

The other scenario is the puncture of the 1,3-Pentadiene (Piperylene) storage tank with a maximum storage capacity of 117,000 pounds in the Tank Farm.  This is the largest storage tank of 1,3-Pentadiene, and the release, estimated at a rate of 14,300 pounds per hour, will be contained in a concrete containment area.  This area is equipped with a deluge system and fire fighting equipment.  Assuming the released 1,3-Pentadiene results in a vapor cloud fire, the estimated affected endpoint is less than 0.1 miles according to the EPA's RMP Comp Modeling Program.  The potential public receptors include employees of the Quality Carriers plant. 1,3-Pentadiene is used to produce specialty anhydrides.


3.0   OVERVIEW OF ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAMS

Gulf Bayport Chemicals, L.P. takes a systematic, proactive approach to preventing accidental releases of hazardous chemicals.  Our management systems address each of the key features of successful prevention programs including:

-  Process safety information
-  Process hazard analysis
-  Operating procedures
-  Training
-  Mechanical integrity
-  Management of change
-  Pre-startup reviews
-  Compliance audits
-  Incident investigation
-  Employee participation
-  Hot work permitting
-  Contractor safety

These individual elements of our prevention program work together to prevent accidental chemical releases.  Our facility and our employees are committed to safe work procedures defined by the prevention program.     We have specific accountabilities and controls to ensure that we are meeting our own high standards for accident prevention.


4.0   FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

Gulf Bayport Chemicals, L.P. has not had any accidental releases from covered processes that have resulted in deaths, injuries, or signific

ant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage during the past five years.


5.0   EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

Gulf Bayport Chemicals, L.P. Emergency Response Program covers various federal, state, and local regulatory requirements for emergency response planning.  We have procedures and training for announcing the accidental releases, contacting the emergency responders, notifying the regulatory agencies and communities, maintaining the emergency response equipment, and handling the emergency incidents.  We have a trained emergency response team on site, and if needed, we coordinate with Channel Industries Mutual Aid (CIMA) for handling larger emergency incidents.  Our emergency response team has training in fire school, rescue training, HAZMAT training, and has conducted joint training and drills with CIMA.  


6.0   PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Gulf Bayport Chemicals, L.P. Plant Safety, Health and Environmental Committee (PSHEC)involves hourly employees by identifying and addressing safety, health, and environmental issues at the facility, in addition to participating in the decision-making process regarding safety, health, and environmental programs. Planned changes to improve safety include expanding our safety observation program, currently conducted by management only, throughout the facility.
